perturbation.explanation: The original clause disclaims 'ANY IMPLIED WARRANTY OF MERCHANTABILITY OR FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE AND IMPLIED WARRANTIES ARISING FROM COURSE OF DEALING OR COURSE OF PERFORMANCE.' The modified clause omits 'AND IMPLIED WARRANTIES ARISING FROM COURSE OF DEALING OR COURSE OF PERFORMANCE.' This omission weakens the consumer protection provided by the implied warranty of performance, creating a legal risk.

perturbation.explanation: The clause 'No settlement or compromise hereunder shall be made which binds the indemnified party without the express written consent of the indemnified party.' has been removed. In many jurisdictions, including both Illinois and New York, an indemnified party has the right to approve any settlement that affects their rights or obligations. Removing this clause allows the indemnifying party to potentially settle claims in a way that is detrimental to the indemnified party, which could violate legal principles of good faith and fair dealing.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Implied Covenant of Good Faith and Fair Dealing

perturbation.original_text: 15.5 Neither party will be liable for, or will be considered to be in breach of or default under this Agreement on account of, any delay or failure to perform as required by this Agreement as a result of any causes or conditions that are beyond such party's reasonable control and that such party is unable to overcome through the exercise of commercially reasonable diligence (a "force majeure event"). perturbation.changed_text: 15.5 Neither party will be liable for, or will be considered to be in breach of or default under this Agreement on account of, any delay or failure to perform as required by this Agreement as a result of any causes or conditions that are beyond such party's reasonable control (a "force majeure event"). If any force majeure event occurs, the affected party will give prompt written notice to the other party and will use commercially reasonable efforts to minimize the impact of the event.
perturbation.explanation: The removal of the clause 'and that such party is unable to overcome through the exercise of commercially reasonable diligence' weakens the requirements for claiming force majeure. Under typical contract law in the US (and in both Illinois and New York, as specified in 15.4), a party invoking force majeure must demonstrate they took reasonable steps to mitigate the impact of the event. Removing this requirement introduces a legal contradiction by making it easier for a party to excuse non-performance due to force majeure, even if they did not act diligently to mitigate the event's impact.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Common Law Principles of Force Majeure
